qas.question: What do computers attached to the ARPANET use for line endings?
What do computers using operating systems use for line endings?
Why did Telnet define an ASCII as a Network Virtual Terminal?

answers.text: so that connections between hosts with different line-ending conventions and character sets could be supported
by transmitting a standard text format over the network

qas.question: Who else adopted this practice from Telnet?
What do computers attached to TENEX use for line endings?
What do computers using standard text format use for line endings?

plausible_answers.text: so that connections between hosts with different line-ending conventions and character sets could be supported

qas.question: Why did Telnet define an ASCII as EBCDIC?

plausible_answers.text: by transmitting a standard text format over the network

qas.question: How were the Network Virtual Terminals supported?
Who else adopted this practice from ASCII?

context: Computers attached to the ARPANET included machines running operating systems such as TOPS-10 and TENEX using <a0_0><b5_0>CR-LF<b5_0/><a0_0/> line endings, machines running operating systems such as Multics using <a1_0><b6_0>LF<b6_0/><a1_0/> line endings, and machines running operating systems such as OS/360 that represented lines as a character count followed by the characters of the line and that used EBCDIC rather than ASCII. The Telnet protocol defined an ASCII "Network Virtual Terminal" (NVT), <a2_0><b7_0>so that connections between hosts with different line-ending conventions and character sets could be supported<b7_0/><a2_0/> <a3_0><b8_0>by transmitting a standard text format over the network<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Telnet used ASCII along with CR-LF line endings, and software using other conventions would translate between the local conventions and the NVT. <a4_0><b9_0>The File Transfer Protocol<b9_0/><a4_0/> adopted the Telnet protocol, including use of the Network Virtual Terminal, for use when transmitting commands and transferring data in the default ASCII mode. This adds complexity to implementations of those protocols, and to other network protocols, such as those used for E-mail and the World Wide Web, on systems not using the NVT's CR-LF line-ending convention.
